Identifying Characteristics: Outside shell is brown-yellow-green in color and has concentric rings
The shell color can flake off and leave white spots
The inner shell is light purple
Size: Juveniles (veligers) are 1mm long when they are discharged, they are about 1cm after one to four years when they reach maturity, adults can be up to 4 or 5cm long
Biology: Males and females are normally distinct (hermaphrodites exist and are capable of self fertilization)
Veligers are discharged from the gills of the parent to begin life as juveniles on the bottom sediments
Under ideal conditions a single clam can release hundreds or even thousands of baby clams a day, up to 70,000 a year
Diet: Filter feeding plankton in large quantities
Habitat: Sandy lake bottoms in large, dense colonies
Moving freshwater bodies with high oxygen levels
Range: Native: Russia, Thailand, thee Philippines, China, Taiwan, Korea, Japan, parts of Africa
Invasive: United States, South and Central America
